text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara011"><span>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have been proved as one of the most alternative to Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) by the virtue of the abundant resources of Na. Among the cathodes, layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a><span> stand out owing to their high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>. The Jahn–Teller distortion, structural phase transition and oxygen release are main drawbacks of Mn/Ni based layered oxides. Hence, Li-Ni-Cu co-substituted Na</span></span><sub>0.67</sub>Li<sub>0.1</sub>(Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>)<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub><span> (NLMNC) sample was prepared. The NLMNC sample exhibits the honeycomb-ordered <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/superlattice" title="Learn more about superstructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superstructure</a> at about 22° which is ascribed to cation ordering. By virtue of the Li-Ni-Cu co-substitute, the Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn is suppressed. Attributed to Li</span><sup>+</sup><span> migrating from the <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxide</a> layer to the interlayer and the Li</span><sup>+</sup> can play the part of pillar in the interlayer, NLMNC cathode displays the capacity retention rate of 82.5 % at 200 mA g<sup>−1</sup><span> after 100 cycles. The anionic <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a><span> of NLMNC is related to the addition of <a href="/topics/materials-science/lithium-ion" title="Learn more about Li ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Li ions</a> and O 2p non-bonding which is different from the anionic redox reaction of electrons removing from O 2p in the e</span></span><sub>g</sub>* (Ni–O) states of Na<sub>2/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. During charge process, peroxo <em>O</em><sup>−</sup><span> emerges with the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> of lattice oxygen. During discharge process, the intensity of peroxo </span><em>O</em><sup>−</sup><span><span> gradually decreases. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> calculations were also carried out to reveal the reaction mechanism of NLMNC. The DFT results showed that the anionic redox reaction occurs near Mn ions, while the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/nickel-ion" title="Learn more about Ni ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ni ions</a><span> are stable which is corresponding with our results. It is proven that such Li-Ni-Cu co-substituted NLMNC presents a promising <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> for SIBs.</span></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724002423"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724002629"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Layered oxides</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Anionic redox</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Superstructure</span></div><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0006">Reaction mechanism</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0004" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">Electrochemical energy storage is relied by the modern society owing to the rapid development and utilization of Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in portable electronic products and electric vehicles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>. With the increasing awareness of environmental protection and the rising price of oil, people are increasingly enthusiastic in electric vehicles which results in the price of lithium resources increasing sharply. Hence, the recent dependence on batteries is greater than ever and the price of lithium resources has been pushed up. It is also noted that most of the world's high-quality lithium resources are concentrated in South America and Australia with geopolitical concerns <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>. Under these circumstances, the calling for alternative batteries becomes even more urgent <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>. Many monovalent and multivalent cation batteries have been studied and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) stand out among these batteries by virtue of the abundant resources corresponding with the low cost, similar charge/discharge mechanism comparing with LIBs and high standard electrode potential <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0004"><span>Cathode, which is considered as the most important parts of the battery, determines the work voltage, rate performance and <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span>. Among these cathodes, such as layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a><span>, polyanionic compounds, Prussian blue and organic compounds, layer oxides attract great attention on account of simple synthesis process and high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a><span>. Layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxides</a> (Na</span><sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, TM referring to transition metals) can be classified into two main group, P2 type (P: prismatic) and O3 type (O: octahedral), depending on the coordination environment of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>. And the numbers "2″ and "3″ are related to the minimum repeated layers. Particularly, manganese-based layered oxides Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> achieve great attention by virtue of the low cost and the environmental friendliness <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. However, the phase transition and the Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn<sup>3+</sup> lead to the serious structural collapse and the rapid capacity fading. In addition, Manthiram's group <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a> reported the mechanism about transition-metal ions with Jahn-Teller distortions dissolving into the electrolytes that high valence state Mn<sup>4+</sup> cations are strong oxidizers which can reduce back directly to the stable state (Mn<sup>2+</sup>) along with oxidizing electrolyte solvent molecules into CO<sub>2</sub> and other substances. In this case, many works found that doping with other elements, such as Li, Mg, Ti, V, Cr, Fe, Ni and so on, can address these problems partially <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0036" name="bbib0036" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0036"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0037" name="bbib0037" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0037"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. It is reported that there are two Na sites called Na<sub>e</sub> site and Na<sub>f</sub> site in the structure of Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> due to the ordering of Na<sup>+</sup> and vacancy. The sodiation/desodiation process of Na in “e” site is faster than that in “f” site. The Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering leads to poor rate performance. Xiao et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a> found that Li and Ti co-doping can suppress such Na<sup>+</sup><span><span>/vacancy ordering and the cathode sodiation/desodiation reaction becomes a completely <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-solution" title="Learn more about solid solution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid solution</a> reaction. Generally, specific </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/semiconductor-doping" title="Learn more about elements doping from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elements doping</a> can endow cathodes improved kinetic process. They demonstrated that the solid-solution reaction region in electrochemical process can be expanded by virtue of the Li and Ti co-doping </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0038" name="bbib0038" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0038"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a><span>. Till now, utilizing both cationic and anionic <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a> is one of the acceptable methods to enhance the energy density of SIBs with layered oxide cathodes. It is reported that monovalent elements, transition metals located on the right side of the periodic table and 4d/5d elements doping can display oxygen redox activities. Many works were carried out because the anxiety of structure stability is growing due to the high expectations of SIBs replacing LIBs in some fields. Introducing Li</span><sup>+</sup> into the transition metal layers which is the similar strategy previously applied to Li-rich layered oxides can activate anionic redox reaction. By virtue of introducing Li<sup>+</sup> into the transition metal layers, the coordination environments of some of O<sup>2−</sup><span> anions change from coordinated with three TM ions to coordinated with one <a href="/topics/materials-science/lithium-ion" title="Learn more about Li ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Li ion</a> and two TM ions. The interaction between Li and O is weaker than the interaction between TM and O resulting in more easily losing electrons from O</span><sup>2−</sup> anions coordinated with both Li and TM. The introduction of Li ions is also related to O holes of oxygen and O 2p non-bonding (O 2p lone pair) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. It is reported that the O 2p non-bonding can maintain the structure stability, while the utilization of TM–O band with anionic activities, such as LiCoO<sub>2</sub>, may lead to the structural failure and oxygen release [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. The charge and discharge processes can empty and fill the O 2p non-bonding [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a><span>]. There are some works reporting about <a href="/topics/materials-science/superlattice" title="Learn more about superstructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superstructure</a> corresponding with outstanding performances. Bruce's group </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a><span> first reported the honeycomb-ordered <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/superlattice" title="Learn more about superstructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superstructure</a> and Ribbon-ordered superstructure which are corresponding with the reversibility of anion redox. A dual-honeycomb superstructure (LiMn</span><sub>6</sub><sub>−</sub>MgMn<sub>6</sub>) in a layered oxide was designed and synthesized by Wang et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0044" name="bbib0044" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0044"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a> The LiMn<sub>6</sub> superlattice activates the anion redox and the MgMn<sub>6</sub> superlattice stabilizes the crystal structure. Currently, the structure change is also the focus of research. Kang's group <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span> studied the migration of TM to the tetrahedral site or octahedral site in the Li layer and in-plane TM migration. They further proved the reason of voltage loss which is related to the migration of TM to other sites. Expect these, large-scale <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-energy-storage" title="Learn more about electrical energy storage from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical energy storage</a><span> system is a significant goal. The preparation and transportation of Na-based layered transition metal oxides are limited by the air stability. Hence, it is important to improve the air stability of layered oxides. It is reported that layered oxides with high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxidation-reduction-potential" title="Learn more about redox potential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox potential</a> couples of Ni</span></span><sup>2+</sup>/<sup>4+</sup> and Cu<sup>2+</sup>/<sup>3+</sup> show much better air-stability than layered oxides with other redox couples <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0045" name="bbib0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. Many other works about air stability are also reported and the storage and transportation capability are simultaneously enhanced <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0046" name="bbib0046" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0046"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0048" name="bbib0048" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0048"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0049" name="bbib0049" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0049"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0005">In this work, Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode (NMNC) and Li-doping Na<sub>0.67</sub>Li<sub>0.1</sub>(Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>)<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NLMNC) cathode were prepared. With the addition of Ni, Cu and Li, the Mn<sup>3+</sup> concentration can be diluted and the Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn<sup>3+</sup> can be suppressed. It is expected that the Li substitution enables the complete solid-solution reaction in a wide voltage range due to the suppression of Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering and the formation of honeycomb-ordered superstructure with Li<sup>+</sup>. In addition, the anionic activities with O 2p non-bonding can be triggered which is corresponding with the good structure stability rather than the remove of electrons from O 2p in the e<sub>g</sub>* (Ni–O) states of Na<sub>2/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a><span>. The cathodes exhibit better air-stability by virtue of the substitution of Mn by Ni and Cu with higher redox potential. Expect these, octahedral-site stabilization energy (OSSE) (OSSE=octahedral <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystal-field-theory" title="Learn more about CFSE from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CFSE</a> - tetrahedral CFSE, crystal field stabilization energies (CFSE)) is also considered. It is hoped that this work can offer a solution toward the design of layered oxides with anionic activity, excellent air-stability and good structure stability.</span></div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0005" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><section id="sec0003"><h3 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Material synthesis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006">Na<sub>0.67</sub>Li<sub>0.1</sub>(Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>)<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub><span> was synthesized via solvothermal method and high-temperature <a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a>. 0.05 mol mixture of MnSO</span><sub>4</sub>, NiSO<sub>4</sub> and CuSO<sub>4</sub><span> (Aladdin, Shanghai, China, in a 0.56:0.16:0.08 M ratio) was dissolved in 50 mL <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a> to get solution A and 0.1 mol NH</span><sub>4</sub>HCO<sub>3</sub> (Aladdin, Shanghai, China) was dissolved in 50 mL deionized water and ethanol mixed solution to get solution B. A and B solutions was mixed together, and the mixed solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The solvothermal reaction was kept at 200 °C for 16 h. The resulting precursor Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> was gathered, rinsed and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C overnight. The spherical precursor Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> (2 g) was mixed with Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> (0.67 g, 10 % in excess) and LiOH and then the mixture was annealed at 900 °C for 12 h to get Na<sub>0.67</sub>Li<sub>0.1</sub>(Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>)<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode. The Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode was obtained without the addition of LiOH.</div></section><section id="sec0004"><h3 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Structure characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">The phase of two cathodes was tested by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on D/max-2200-PC. The elements concentration was recorded by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) on AGILENT ICPOES 730. Nanobrook 90Plus was used to test the particle size. The morphologies of two cathodes were tested by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on ZEISS microscope (SIGMA) and high-resolution <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (HRTEM) on JEOL-2100F. The surface compositions were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on Nexsa Surface Analysis System.</div></section><section id="sec0005"><h3 id="cesectitle0008" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0008"><span><span>Spin-polarized DFT calculations were carried out using the Vienna <a href="/topics/materials-science/ab-initio-simulation" title="Learn more about ab initio simulation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ab initio simulation</a> package (VASP) with plane wave basis sets and projector-augmented wave (PAW) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/pseudopotential" title="Learn more about pseudopotentials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudopotentials</a>. Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized-gradient approximation (GGA) was adopted to describe the exchange-correlation functionals. The energy cutoff of 500 eV was used for all calculations and the convergence criterion for energy and force for structural relaxation were set as 1.0 × 10−4 eV and 0.02 eV </span><em>Å</em>−1. A Monkhorst–Pack mesh of 3 × 3 × 2 k-points was used for structural relaxation, while a 9 × 9 × 2 k-point mesh was used for static and non-static calculations. The effects of the localized electronic states of d electron of transition metal were taken into account with GGA + <em>U</em> method, and the U values for Ni 3d, Cu 3d and Mn 3d states were set to be 6.0 eV, 4.0 eV and 3.9 eV, respectively.</div></section><section id="sec0006"><h3 id="cesectitle0009" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009"><span>In process of preparing the working electrodes, active material, conductive carbon black and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a><span> fluoride were mixed together at a weight ratio of 8:1:1 with N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP) as a solution. The suspension was coated on <a href="/topics/materials-science/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminum foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum foil</a> with the areal densities of 2 to 3 mg cm</span></span><sup>−2</sup><span>. The CR2032 coin cells were assembled with working electrodes, metallic <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> foil, glass fiber and electrolyte ((1 mol L</span><sup>−1</sup> NaClO<sub>4</sub> dissolved in ethyl carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC) (1:1 vol%) with 5 vol% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC)) in an argon-filled glove box.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0010"><span>The galvanostatic discharge/charge tests were carried out on LAND CT3001A (Wuhan, China) with the test voltage range from 2.1 to 4.3 V. <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) was performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI760E) under the potential window from 2.1 to 4.3 V at the rate of 0.1 mV s</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. The electrochemical workstation is also used to study <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS).</span></div></section></section><section id="sec0007"><h2 id="cesectitle0010" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec0008"><h3 id="cesectitle0011" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Characterization and structure analysis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0011">The synthetic process of both samples is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Scheme 1</span></span></a>. Due to the inevitable dissolution of NH<sub>4</sub>HCO<sub>3</sub><span>, there is a little amount of precipitate appearing which offers a core for the spherical precursor growing up. The spherical precursor was mixed with stoichiometric amounts of lithium/sodium salt and the mixture was heated in air. Owing to the different diffusion rate, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/kirkendall-effect" title="Learn more about kirkendall effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kirkendall effect</a> occurs during the heat-treating process resulting in the homogeneous polyhedra hollow structure.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-sc1.jpg" height="89" alt="Scheme 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-sc1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (222KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (222KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-sc1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Scheme 1</span>. Schematic illustration of the preparation of layered oxides. (M: Mn, Ni and Cu).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0012">The results of ICP tests are shown in Table S1 for revealing the chemical compositions. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1a</span></span></a><span>, the crystal structures of NMNC and NLMNC samples were determined by <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a>. All the diffraction peaks can be assigned to the P2-type layered structure with the hexagonal lattice corresponding with the space group of P6</span><sub>3</sub>/<em>mmc</em><span>. It can be revealed that the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a> and the purity of NMNC and NLMNC are good by virtue of the sharp peaks and no impurity peaks. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1b</span></span></a><span><span>, the NLMNC sample exhibits the honeycomb-ordered <a href="/topics/materials-science/superlattice" title="Learn more about superstructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superstructure</a><span> at about 22° which is ascribed to cation ordering with Li in the transition metal layer. Such <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/superlattice" title="Learn more about superstructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superstructure</a> is corresponding with one Li-ion surrounded by six transition-metal ions owing to the mismatch of ionic valence and radius. The </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> result of NLMNC sample with rational R</span><sub>wp</sub> is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1b</span></span></a><span><span> and Table S2 for getting further information about the crystal structure. The Li and <a href="/topics/materials-science/copper-ion" title="Learn more about Cu ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cu ions</a> are successfully introduced into transition metal layers. </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a> occupy two distinct Wyckoff sites, Na</span><sub>e</sub> site and Na<sub>f</sub> site. By virtue of the Li substitution, Na ions tend to occupy Na<sub>e</sub> site and the Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering is suppressed. The schematic illustration of honeycomb-ordered superstructure is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1c</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">d</span></span></a>. It is reported that Li<sup>+</sup> will migrate irreversibly from transitional metal layers to interlayers and the honeycomb-ordered superstructure is corresponding with oxygen redox activities <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. It is expected that the Li<sup>+</sup><span> ions migrate to <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/alkali-metal" title="Learn more about alkali metal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">alkali metal</a> layers can support the structure leading to the great cycling performance.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr1.jpg" height="546" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0002"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (981KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (981KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) Powder <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a><span><span> of NMNC and NLMNC with the inset of details <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> from 20° to 30° (b) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/powder-x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about Powder XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Powder XRD</a><span> patterns with <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> of NLMNC. (c) Schematic illustration of NLMNC with superstructure. (d) Single superstructure of one Li-ion surrounded by six transition-metal ions.</span></span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0013">The SEM images of NMNC and NLMNC are exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2a</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">b</span></span></a><span>, respectively. It is vividly shown that there is no significant difference between NMNC sample and NLMNC sample. Both samples display a homogeneous polyhedra hollow structure. Such homogeneous polyhedra hollow structure is related to low volume change and good <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a><span> during <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a><span> processes. Nano-Brook 90plus PALS was used to reveal <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a>, the result is shown in Fig. S1 that the average pore size of NLMNC sample is about 2.1 μm. With the aim of studying the surface area of NLMNC sample, BET (Brunaurer-emmett-teller ASAP 2020) was carried out. As exhibited in Fig. S2, the NLMNC sample exhibits large BET surface area of 30.29 m</span></span></span><sup>2</sup>·g<sup>−1</sup>. For a more convincing description, TEM images of NLMNC sample are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2c</span></span></a>. The hollow structure is also proved as shown in the inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2c</span></span></a>. As revealed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2c</span></span></a><span>, the interference fringe spacing (d-spacings of the (002) plane) of NLMNC sample is 0.55 nm. For further examining the distribution of elements, <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping of NLMNC sample is shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2d</span></span></a><span>. It is vividly exhibited that <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a>, manganese, nickel and cuprum elements are extremely uniform in the NLMNC sample.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr2.jpg" height="436" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a) SEM images of NMNC sample. (b) SEM images of NLMNC sample. (c) TEM images of NLMNC sample at high magnifications with the inset at low magnifications. (d) <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping of NLMNC sample. XPS of (e) Mn 2p, (f) Ni 2p and (g) Cu 2p of both samples.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0014"><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> was performed to further reveal the surface elemental composition of NLMNC and NMNC, as exhibited in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2e</span></span></a>–<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">g</span></span></a>. With the addition of Li, the XPS Mn 2p spectrum of NLMNC is different from that of NMNC. The intensity of peaks for Mn<sup>4+</sup> of NLMNC at 642.5/654.0 eV are stronger than that of NMNC at 642.8/654.3 eV which reveals the addition of Li<sup>+</sup> resulting in the increase in the average valence state of Mn. The relative content of Mn<sup>4+</sup> and Mn<sup>3+</sup> of two samples is exhibited in Table S3 which clearly reveals the higher content of Mn<sup>4+</sup> in NLMNC. It is widely acknowledged that the Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn<sup>3+</sup> will lead to the serious structural collapse and the increase in the average valence state of Mn is meaningful for suppressing the Jahn–Teller distortion. Reducing the Mn<sup>3+</sup> content and increasing Mn<sup>4+</sup> content in NLMNC can improve the cycling performance. By the XPS analysis of Ni 2p, two peaks of NMNC located at 854.5 eV and 872.0 eV can be ascribed to Ni 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Ni 2p<sub>1/2</sub><span>. Such result displays the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> state of Ni in NMNC is divalent. However, there are four peaks located at 854.1/871.6 eV and 856.3/874.9 eV after the addition of Li in NLMNC, which are corresponding with the oxidation state of divalent and trivalent. Both samples show complex satellite peaks which are belong to Ni compounds. The XPS fitted peak results for Cu 2p of NLMNC and NMNC are also similar. The peaks at 933.2 eV and 932.7 eV are corresponding with Cu 2p</span><sub>3/2</sub> and the peaks at 952.5 eV and 952.5 eV can be ascribed to Cu 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and one satellite exhibiting in both samples. It reveals the Cu in the chemical environment of Cu<sup>2+</sup>.</div></section><section id="sec0009"><h3 id="cesectitle0012" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemical performances</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0015">The electrochemical energy storage behaviors of NLMNC and NMNC are tested <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3a</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">b</span></span></a> exhibits the initial charge-discharge curves of NLMNC and NMNC at current densities of 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. Several voltage plateaus exist in the initial charge-discharge curves of NMNC. While, almost none of the platforms appear in the initial charge-discharge curves of NLMNC from 2.1 V to 4.0 V. Especially, the high voltage plateaus of NMNC at about 4.2 V may be related to the electrochemical oxidation of Cu<sup>2+</sup> to Cu<sup>3+</sup> and Ni<sup>3+</sup> to Ni<sup>4+</sup>, phase transition and oxygen redox. Such high voltage plateaus are not obvious in the curves of NLMNC revealing the riveting Li<sup>+</sup> can bring O 2p non-bonding, disrupt the Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering and expand the range of solid-solution. Comparing with the NMNC cathodes, the NLMNC cathode exhibits smooth and sloping profiles which is related to the structural stability. The initial charge/discharge capacity of NLMNC is 163.0/116.1 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> with the coulombic efficiency of 71.2 % indicating that the Li<sup>+</sup> migrate from transitional metal layers to interlayers resulting in the low coulombic efficiency <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3c</span></span></a> exhibits the cycling performance of NLMNC and NMNC at current densities of 20 mA·g<sup>−1</sup>. It is clearly shown that the discharge capacity of NLMNC is higher than that of NMNC. During the previous cycling processes, there is a small increase in the discharge capacity of NLMNC which is relative to the activated process and the migration of Li<sup>+</sup>. The rate capabilities are performed under the current densities of 20, 50, 100, 200 and 20 mA·g<sup>−1</sup>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3d</span></span></a>. The average capacities of NLMNC are higher than those of NMNC and the gap is getting wider with the increase of current densities. Furthermore, NLMNC and NMNC cathodes are tested at 200 mA g<sup>−1</sup> for 100 circles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3e</span></span></a>). The initial discharge capacity of NLMNC is 102.1 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> and the highest discharge capacity is 111.3 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after the activated process. After 100 cycles, the capacity retention rate of NLMNC is 82.5 % (based on the discharge capacity of initial cycle) which is obviously better than that of NMNC. In addition, the charge/discharge curves of the 2nd, 25th, 50th, 70th and 100th cycles are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3f</span></span></a> for further revealing the electrochemical behaviors of NLMNC. It's clearly shown that there is a small voltage drop (0.2467 V) from 2nd to 100th. The cutoff potential drop may be related to the migration of Li<sup>+</sup> corresponding with the dissolution of a small quantity of manganese. However, the discharge capacity of NMNC dropped from 93.8 to 26.8 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> which is much worse than that of NLMNC. Such phenomenon is related to the serious Jahn–Teller distortion and low octahedral-site stabilization energy (OSSE) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0050" name="bbib0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3g</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">h</span></span></a><span> shows the Cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves of NMNC cathode and NLMNC cathode as a way to better figure out the electrochemical processes. It is vividly shown that the <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of NMNC cathode is corresponding with the initial charge-discharge curves (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3 g</span></span></a>). There is a pair of oxidation and reduction peaks at about 4.2 V and 4.05 V which can be related to the electrochemical oxidation of Cu<sup>2+</sup> to Cu<sup>3+</sup>and Ni<sup>3+</sup> to Ni<sup>4+</sup>, phase transition and oxygen redox [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0051" name="bbib0051" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0051"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. However, the reduction peak at about 4.05 V which exhibits poor reversibility in long cycling disappears in the CV curves of NLMNC cathode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3h</span></span></a>). It is attributed to the addition of Li that suppresses the oxygen release. For conventional Na<sub>2/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, the electron can be removed from O 2p in the e<sub>g</sub>* (Ni–O) states <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>. It is reported that the Ni-O bond is the weakest in the M-O bonds which may lead to the structural failure <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0052" name="bbib0052" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. While the electron removed from O 2p non-bonding corresponding with the addition of Li ions can maintain the structural stability by generating peroxo-like O–O species. Furthermore, when Li<sup>+</sup> was introduced into NMNC, the original peaks became broadened which is related to the voltage plateaus became sloping (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3a</span></span></a>). Furthermore, GITT test (the second cycle) was done to evaluate the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion in NMNC cathode and NLMNC cathode, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3i</span></span></a> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">j</span></span></a><span>. The chemical <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> is corresponding with the following <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0001" name="beqn0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Eq. (1)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0001" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac
