is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow><mi is="true">S</mi></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mstyle mathvariant="normal" is="true"><mi is="true">Δ</mi></mstyle><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mstyle mathvariant="normal" is="true"><mi is="true">Δ</mi></mstyle><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr3.jpg" height="441" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (719KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (719KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) Initial charge-discharge curves of NLMNC cathode at 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>. (b) Initial charge-discharge curves of NMNC cathode at 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>. (c) Cycling performance of NLMNC and NMNC at current densities of 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>. (d) Rate capability of NLMNC and NMNC. (e) Cycling performance of NLMNC and NMNC at current densities of 200 mA g<sup>−1</sup>. (f) Charge/discharge curves of the 2nd, 25th, 50th, 70th and 100th cycles. (g) CV curves of NMNC cathode in the initial 3 cycles. (h) CV curves of NLMNC cathode. (i) Galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) of NMNC cathode. (j) GITT of NLMNC cathode. (k) Calculated Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> of NMNC cathode. (l) Calculated Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> of NLMNC cathode.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0016">Where, ∆E<sub>s</sub> and ∆E<sub>t</sub>, getting from the GITT results, refer to the change of voltage for resting and cycling, respectively. The τ, n<sub>m</sub>, V<sub>m</sub><span> and S in this equation are related to the time duration, molar concentration, <a href="/topics/materials-science/density-specific-gravity" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a> and the active surface of the electrode. After calculating, the obtained D</span><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> for NLMNC electrode during the charge process is about 10<sup>−11</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3l</span></span></a>). However, there are large fluctuations in the obtained D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> for NMNC electrode during the charge process from 10<sup>−11</sup>–10<sup>−13</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3k</span></span></a>) which may be associated with the phase transition and oxygen redox activities. Furthermore, the average obtained D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> for NLMNC electrode during the discharge process is smaller than that of NMNC. Such result exhibits NLMNC electrode owning facile Na<sup>+</sup> transport contributing to the electrochemical performances.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0017"><span><span>For exploring the change of impedance corresponding with cationic and anionic <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a>, potential-based in-situ </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (PBIS-EIS) measurements of NLMNC electrode during the second charge process were performed. The amplitude of PBIS-EIS was 10 mV and the frequency range was 1 Hz to 100 kHz. The 3D Bode-Phase plot (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4a</span></span></a>) is corresponding with the frequency, voltage and phase angle. As the cationic redox reaction occurs at the beginning of charging, the phase angles in the frequency range of 1–100 Hz become bigger. With the reaction stabilizing and the reduction of charge, the charge transfer resistance become smaller. After charging to 3.5 V, the phase angles in the frequency range of 1–100 Hz become bigger again till 4.0 V which is corresponding with the occurrence of Ni<sup>3+</sup>/Ni<sup>4+</sup> and anionic redox reaction. These phenomena are also revealed by vertical views of differential Nyquist plots as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4b</span></span></a>. The bar-colorimetric card from blue to red is corresponding with the value of d(-Z’’)/d(Z’). The higher the slope of the impedance semicircle is, the bluer the color is. The Nyquist plots of NLMNC cathode at different selected voltages are also exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4c</span></span></a>. The trend mentioned above can also be well observed. The anionic redox reaction at high voltage is the main reason for the increase of impedance.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr4.jpg" height="160" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (360KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (360KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="spara005"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) 3D Bode-Phase plot. (b) Vertical views of differential Nyquist plots. (c) Nyquist plots of NLMNC cathode at different voltages.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec0010"><h3 id="cesectitle0013" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Reaction mechanism</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0018">As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5a</span></span></a><span>, in-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of NLMNC cathode during the first charge/discharge processes are exhibited. All the diffraction peaks of NLMNC cathode during the first charge/discharge processes can be corresponding with the XRD of original NLMNC except the diffraction peaks of Be. To further reveal the movement of the (002), (004), (100) and (012) reflections, the detailed information of these reflections of NLMNC cathode is shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5b</span></span></a>–<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">e</span></span></a>. It is revealed that the (002) and (004) diffraction peaks shift to low angles related to the expansion of c-lattice during the charging process along with the (100) and (012) diffraction peaks shift to high angles. The change of (002) and (004) diffraction peaks which is resulting from the fast insertion of Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> ions corresponding with the change of Ni-O. The Ni atom can obtain more electrons leading to the change of <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxide</a> layer. During the discharging process, all diffraction peak returns back. The </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> during the first charge/discharge processes are small. These phenomena benefit from the block of phase transition from P2 to O2 and results in good structural stability.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0006"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr5.jpg" height="521" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0006"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0006"><p id="spara006"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) In-situ XRD patterns of NLMNC cathode during the first charge/discharge processes. Contour maps of selected 2θ regions of in-situ XRD patterns indicating the evolution of (b) 002, (c) 004, (d) 100 and (e) 012 reflections.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0019"><span>For revealing the condition of honeycomb-ordered superstructure and the existence of Li ions, detail <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> from 20° to 30° and ex-situ XPS results of Li 1 s are exhibited in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6a</span></span></a>, there is a Li 1 s peak of pristine NLMNC exhibiting at about 53 eV. The pristine NLMNC sample exhibits the honeycomb-ordered superstructure at about 22° (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6d</span></span></a>). After charging to 4.3 V, there is a slight shift of Li 1 s peak to 55 eV as exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6b</span></span></a>. There is no peak of honeycomb-ordered superstructure (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6e</span></span></a>). This phenomenon may be related to Li ions migrating from the transition metal site to the alkali site in the interlayer during the charging process. The Li 1 s peak stables at about 55 eV after discharging to 2.1 eV (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6c</span></span></a>). The peak of honeycomb-ordered superstructure cannot be recovered. The loss of superstructure peak may be originated from the loss of honeycomb ordering corresponding with the migration of Mn ions. By virtue of the migration of Li<sup>+</sup><span> from the metal <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> layer to the interlayer during cycling, the Li</span><sup>+</sup> act as a pillar for ensuring the interlayer spacing which can reduce the interaction of O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O and enhance the cycling stability. The schematic diagram of NLMNC cathode during cycling is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6 g</span></span></a>. After initial cycling, the Li<sup>+</sup><span> migrate from the <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxide</a> layer to the interlayer corresponding with the Li</span><sup>+</sup> can play the part of pillar in the interlayer during later cycling. In addition, the electrons remove from O 2p non-bonding also resulting from the vacancies from the migration of Li ions.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0007"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr6.jpg" height="516" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0007"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (901KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (901KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0007"><p id="spara007"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. XPS of Li 1 s of (a) pristine NLMNC, (b) NLMNC after charging to 4.3 V and (c) NLMNC after discharging to 2.1 V. Details XRD patterns from 20° to 30° of (d) pristine NLMNC, (e) NLMNC after charging to 4.3 V and (f) NLMNC after discharging to 2.1 V. (g) The schematic diagram of NLMNC cathode during cycling. (Blue and yellow balls are represented Li<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup>, respectively.).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0020">The charge transfer mechanism of NLMNC cathode with outstanding electrochemical performance was further revealed by ex-situ XPS. Ex-situ XPS of Mn 2p of NLMNC is shown in Fig. S3. During the charge process, the intensity of Mn<sup>4+</sup> increases. Till 4.3 V, the Mn 2p peaks are almost full of Mn<sup>4+</sup>. Then the intensity of Mn<sup>4+</sup> decreases with the discharge process. Furthermore, ex-situ XPS of Ni 2p and Cu 2p of NLMNC cathode at different charge/discharge states were performed for understanding the change of surface elemental composition of NLMNC as exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7a</span></span></a>–<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">b</span></span></a>. During the first cycle, Mn keeps the state of +4. It is revealed that Ni<sup>2+</sup> is gradually oxidized to Ni<sup>3+</sup> and Ni<sup>4+</sup> during the charge process and the intensity of Ni<sup>2+</sup> and Ni<sup>3+</sup> increases during the discharge process. There is a shift of the XPS results of Cu 2p corresponding with the oxidation of Cu<sup>2+</sup> to Cu<sup>3+</sup>. Such change is related to the riveting of Li<sup>+</sup>, which can promote the oxidation of Cu. In addition, the valence state change can suppress the Jahn–Teller distortion of Cu<sup>2+</sup>. With the aim of exploring the state of oxygen, ex-situ XPS of O is at different charge/discharge states are tested and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7c</span></span></a>. The orange line in O 1 s ex-situ XPS peak is corresponding with lattice O<sup>2−</sup> and the blue line is related to the surface species such as the carbonate and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O/C = O species. During the charge process (beginning at 4.0 V), the new peaks observed at around 532.5 eV are assigned to the formation of peroxo <em>O</em><sup>−</sup> with the oxidation of lattice oxygen. During the discharge process, the intensity of peroxo <em>O</em><sup>−</sup> gradually decreases, which exhibits the anionic redox reaction is highly reversible. Such phenomenon is different form the anionic redox reaction corresponding with the electrons removing from O 2p in the e<sub>g</sub>* (Ni–O) states of Na<sub>2/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0008"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr7.jpg" height="803" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0008"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0008"><p id="spara008"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. Ex-situ XPS of (a) Ni 2p, (b) Cu 2p and (c) O 1 s of NLMNC cathode at different charge/discharge states.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0021">Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to reveal the reaction mechanism of NLMNC. The results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0009" name="bfig0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> and Fig. S4. By virtue of the addition of Cu, the valence state of Mn is enhanced which stabilize the Mn ions in the structure. This phenomenon is related to the Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn<sup>3+</sup><span>. It can be observed that the valence states of Mn during cycling change a lot. In addition to Mn becoming stable, <a href="/topics/materials-science/nickel-ion" title="Learn more about Ni ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ni ions</a> also become stable. The anionic redox reaction corresponding with the electrons removing from O 2p in the e</span><sub>g</sub>* (Ni–O) states is hard to occur. It reveals that the anionic redox reaction will occur near the Mn ions. These results tally with the electrochemical processes. The Li<sup>+</sup><span> ions migrate from the metal oxide layer to the interlayer during the first cycling process and this process leave vacancy in the metal oxide layer which is correlated with the formation of O 2p non-bonding. This process can control the fast electron loss of Ni ions. All in all, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> results show that the anionic redox reaction occurs close to Mn ions corresponding with the O 2p non-bonding rather than the electrons removing from e</span><sub>g</sub>* (Ni–O) states.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0009"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr8.jpg" height="525" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="cap0009"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (654KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (654KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0009"><p id="spara009"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (a) DOS of Na<sub>2/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. (b) DOS of Na<sub>0</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. (c) DOS of Na<sub>0.67</sub>Li<sub>0.1</sub>(Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>)<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. (d) DOS of Na<sub>0</sub>Li<sub>0.1</sub>(Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>)<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0022">It is acknowledged that the electronic configuration of Cu<sup>2+</sup> is (t<sub>2g</sub>)<sup>6</sup>(e<sub>g</sub>)<sup>3</sup> which is high-spin and unstable. While the electronic configuration of Cu<sup>3+</sup> is (t<sub>2g</sub>)<sup>6</sup>(e<sub>g</sub>)<sup>2</sup> which is more stable than Cu<sup>2+</sup><span>. It is also can be compared by octahedral-site stabilization energy (OSSE) (OSSE=octahedral <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystal-field-theory" title="Learn more about CFSE from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CFSE</a> - tetrahedral CFSE, crystal field stabilization energies (CFSE)). Here, octahedral-site stabilization energy (OSSE) (OSSE=octahedral CFSE - tetrahedral CFSE, crystal field stabilization energies (CFSE)) is mentioned to compare the stability of different valence states. The crystal field stabilization energies (CFSE) of 3d transitional metals can be determined through </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0002" name="beqn0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Eq. (2)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0002" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(10138,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28" is="true"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-64"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(520,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B3"></use></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" is="true" x="1394" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(12144,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(13145,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(600,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1276,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2277,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(600,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3721,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(17422,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-50"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mi is="true">F</mi><mi is="true">S</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">x</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">ε</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">y</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mi is="true">γ</mi></msub><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mi is="true">P</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mi is="true">F</mi><mi is="true">S</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">x</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">ε</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">y</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mi is="true">γ</mi></msub><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mi is="true">P</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where x, y, n<sub>2</sub> and n<sub>1</sub> refer to the number of electrons in dε, the number of electrons in d<sub>γ</sub>, the number of electron pairs in d orbital of complex and the number of electron pairs in d orbital of 3d transitional metals, respectively. P stands for the pairing energies which is ignored in calculation for simplicity. The Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn can also be explained by OSSE. For Mn<sup>3+</sup> and Mn<sup>4+</sup>, the calculated OSSE are −0.422Δ<sub>o</sub> and −0.844Δ<sub>o</sub> (Δ<sub>o</sub> Refers to octahedral-site splitting) leading to better stability of Mn<sup>4+</sup>. Put in simple terms, Mn<sup>3+</sup> ions tend to be more stable in tetrahedral site while Mn ions stand in octahedral site in the structure of P2 phase. Hence, the valence state of Mn increasing is beneficial for stabling the structure by virtue of the low valence state of Cu and Li. It is acknowledged that the electronic configuration of Cu<sup>2+</sup> is (t<sub>2g</sub>)<sup>6</sup>(e<sub>g</sub>)<sup>3</sup> which is high-spin and unstable. While the electronic configuration of Cu<sup>3+</sup> is (t<sub>2g</sub>)<sup>6</sup>(e<sub>g</sub>)<sup>2</sup> which is stabler than Cu<sup>2+</sup>. After calculating, the OSSE of Cu<sup>2+</sup> and Cu<sup>3+</sup> are −0.422Δ<sub>o</sub> and −0.844Δ<sub>o</sub>. The higher the absolute value of OSSE, the more stable the structure is. Hence, the cycling stability of NLMNC is also enhanced by virtue of the addition of Li which can promote the reduction of Cu. Here, there is one more point which is also important needing to be mentioned that the same transition metal ion with different valence states and OSSE own different performances.</div></section><section id="sec0011"><h3 id="cesectitle0014" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. Air stability</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0023">Air stability is another critical factor for these layered oxide cathodes. The structure and electrochemical performance of NLMNC sample after stored in air for 7 days were characterized and tested. There is no new peak shown in the result of XRD revealing the good air stability (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 9a</span></span></a>). The honeycomb-ordered superstructure peak is also shown at about 22 ° In addition, the morphology is also reserved well confirmed by the SEM in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 9b</span></span></a>. The rate and cycling performances for both samples is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 9c</span></span></a>. The rate performance of NLMNC sample after stored in air for 7 days is almost the same as pristine NLMNC sample. The rate performance of NLMNC sample after stored in air for 7 days at 200 mA g<sup>−1</sup> is a little worse than pristine NLMNC sample. It may be related to the small amounts of H<sub>2</sub>O and CO<sub>2</sub> reacting with NLMNC sample corresponding with <em>H</em><sup>+</sup> ions block the interlayer of NLMNC sample. The cycling performance NLMNC sample after stored in air for 7 days almost overlays with that of the pristine one at 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>. These results indicate the NLMNC cathode owns good air stability which is suitable for preparation, storage and transportation in the industry.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr9.jpg" height="152" alt="Fig. 9" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr9_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (319KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (319KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724002514-gr9.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="spara010"><span class="label">Fig. 9</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/powder-x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about Powder XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Powder XRD</a> patterns of pristine NLMNC and NLMNC after being stored in air for 7 days with the inset of details XRD patterns from 20° to 30° (b) SEM image of NLMNC after being stored in air for 7 days. (c) Rate performances of NLMNC and NLMNC after being stored in air for 7 days with the inset of cycling performances at 20 mA </span><em>g</em> <sup>−</sup> <sup>1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="sec0012"><h2 id="cesectitle0015" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0024"><span><span>In summary, NMNC sample and NLMNC sample were prepared via <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal method</a><span> and <a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a>. The NLMNC sample exhibits the honeycomb-ordered superstructure that one Li-ion surrounded by six transition-metal atoms. Both samples display a homogeneous polyhedra hollow structure which is related to low volume change and good </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a>. By virtue of the introduction of Li</span><sup>+</sup><span>, the Jahn–Teller distortion of NLMNC is suppressed due to the increased average valence state of Mn, which optimizes its cycling performance. The outstanding <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performances from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performances</a> are related to Li</span><sup>+</sup><span> migrating from the <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxide</a> layer to the interlayer corresponding with the promotion of the Cu redox and the Li</span><sup>+</sup> can play the part of pillar in the interlayer. Owing to the electrons removing from O 2p non-bonding by the addition of Li ions and honeycomb-ordered superstructure, the oxygen release and structural failure by electrons removing from e<sub>g</sub><span>* (Ni–O) states are suppressed. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> results also reveal these mechanisms that the anionic redox reaction occurs close to Mn ions corresponding with the O 2p non-bonding rather than the electrons removing from e</span><sub>g</sub><span>* (Ni–O) states. In addition, the co-substituted strategy can enhance the air stability. It is hoped that this co-substituted strategy will provide guidance for future work. Some other inactive elements, such as Ti, Zn, Sn, etc., can also be attempted to be added for stabilizing the oxide and playing the part of pillar. We believe that such outstanding NLMNC cathode will lead the way for practical application of layered oxides in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div></section><section id="sec0012a"><h2 id="cesectitle0015a" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0024a"><strong>Wenyu Yin:</strong> Methodology, Investigation. <strong>Zhixiong Huang:</strong> Software, Methodology, Investigation. <strong>Tengfei Zhang:</strong> Software, Formal analysis. <strong>Tianqi Yang:</strong> Software, Data curation. <strong>Houpeng Ji:</strong> Investigation, Methodology. <strong>Yujia Zhou:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Shaojun Shi:</strong> Data curation, Formal analysis, Resources, Software, Validation, Writing – original draft, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Yongqi Zhang:</strong> Resources, Supervision, Visualization, Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0016" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0026">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle8812" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para1119a">This work was financially supported by National Nautral Science Foundation of China (21701017), Key Research and Development Project of Science and Technology Department of Sichuan Province (2022YFSY0004) and <span id="gs00001">Natural Science Foundation of Chongqing</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs00001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">CSTB2022NSCQ-MSX0487</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="sec0014"><h2 id="cesectitle9002" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix. 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723012377" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View article</span></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Tuning%20oxygen%20release%20of%20sodium-ion%20layered%20oxide%20cathode%20through%20synergistic%20surface%20coating%20and%20doping&amp;publication_year=2023&amp;author=X.-L.%20Zhang&amp;author=Z.-X.%20Huang&amp;author=Y.-N.%20Liu&amp;author=M.-Y.%20Su&amp;author=K.%20Li&amp;author=X.-L.%20Wu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (10)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0032591024009586"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Suppressing the P2–OP4 phase transition of single-crystal P2-type Ni/Zn/Mn-based layered oxide for advanced sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Powder Technology</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Therefore, P2-type oxide cathodes possess higher rate capability, working voltage, energy density, and cycling stability. P2-type manganese-rich layered oxides have been recommended as one of most competitive cathode materials, profited from their high operating voltage, high specific capacity, fast Na+ diffusion kinetics, low production cost, and simple synthesis process [34–36]. P2-type Na0.67Ni0.33Mn0.67O2 is considered to be the first choice of cathode materials for SIBs owing to its many advantages, including easy synthesis, ecofriendliness, fast Na+ diffusion kinetics, low production cost, and exceptional properties (such as, high specific capacity and working voltage) [32,37–39].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060">P2-type layered Na<sub>0.66</sub>Ni<sub>0.26</sub>Zn<sub>0.07</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NNZM) is expected to be a competitive alternative to lithium layered oxide due to its high-energy-density, low production cost, and high-speed Na<sup>+</sup> ion transport channels. However, it is still necessary to further improve its air stability and cycle life to meet the needs of practical applications. Single crystals with micron-scale have smaller specific surface area and greater packing density, which can improve air stability and cycle life compared to the traditional polycrystalline. Herein, single-crystal Na<sub>0.66</sub>Ni<sub>0.26</sub>Zn<sub>0.07</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (SC-NNZM) is prepared by using Na<sub>2</sub>MoO<sub>4</sub> as the molten salt. Driven by molten salt Na<sub>2</sub>MoO<sub>4</sub>, regular hexagonal prism morphology SC-NNZM with a median diameter (D50) of 7.86&nbsp;μm and the (001) plane-dominated structure is obtained, larger than that (5.05&nbsp;μm) of single-crystal C-NNZM without Na<sub>2</sub>MoO<sub>4</sub>, implying that specific surface area of SC-NNZM is smaller than that of C-NNZM, thereby reducing the contact area of SC-NNZM with the electrolyte, which is good for suppressing both harmful interface side-reactions and phase transitions at high voltages. Therefore, SC-NNZM exhibits 95.44&nbsp;% capacity retention at 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 100&nbsp;cycles, higher than C-NNZM (86.09&nbsp;%). Moreover, rate capability of SC-NNZM is also higher than that of C-NNZM. This study provides a new strategy for inducing crystal plane growth that is conducive to the structure stability of single-crystal layered oxide at high voltages.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894724087552"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Research progress on P2-type layered oxide cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Engineering Journal</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">The P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> material, renowned for the high sodium-ion (Na<sup>+</sup>) diffusion rate and conductivity, exhibits remarkable rate capability and cycling performance, making it a promising candidate for the cathode of SIBs. However, the performance of the P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode is hindered due to high-voltage phase transitions, structural reconstructions, oxygen release, metal dissolution, and air sensitivity. To cope with these problems, rational component regulation and structural design have been explored in recent years, but lack of systematic analysis and organization. Herein, from the relationship between the structure and performance of materials, the related mechanisms that give rise to these problems, and the advancements in modifying P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode through various strategies including element doping, surface engineering, multiphase composites, and innovative configuration designs are reviewed comprehensively. Finally, some insights on the innovative research direction, potential modification strategies, and development trends of P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode are presented. This review will supply a reference for the component regulation and structural design of the P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode, expected to facilitate the practical application of the P2-type layered oxide cathodes.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1359836824004761"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Constructing layered/tunnel interlocking oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries based on breaking Mn&lt;sup&gt;3+&lt;/sup&gt;/Mn&lt;sup&gt;4+&lt;/sup&gt; equilibrium in Na&lt;inf&gt;0.44&lt;/inf&gt;MnO&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; via trace Mo doping</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Composites Part B: Engineering</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">In addition, the existence of P2-type layered and tunnel structure was confirmed by the TEM. The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images in Fig. 1f,g and Figs. S1a and b exhibit the lattice fringes of 0.55 and 0.28 nm, corresponding to the (002) and (004) crystal planes of the P2 phase [49,50]. And the amplified rectangle area in Fig. 1h is shown in Fig. 1i, which show a lattice distance of about 0.26 nm (Fig. S1c), corresponding to the (350) plane of the tunnel structure.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with Mn-based oxide cathodes have attracted much interest because of their cost effectiveness, minimal toxicity, and remarkable electrochemical activity. The typical tunnel Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode for SIBs exhibits stable cycling performance, but its low sodium content hinders the practical application. And the other Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes with layered structures provide higher capacity but less satisfactory cycling. Therefore, it is of great significance to construct Mn-based oxide cathodes to integrate high specific capacity layered structure and high stability tunnel structure. Herein, the strategy of breaking the Mn<sup>3+</sup>/Mn<sup>4+</sup> equilibrium in Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> via doping trace amounts of Mo was proposed to promote the transformation from the original tunnel to the layered structure and to <em>in-situ</em> construct a layered/tunnel biphasic interlocking structure. The optimized interlocking layered/tunnel Na<sub>0.44</sub>Mn<sub>0.97</sub>Mo<sub>0.03</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NMO-3M) cathode integrates the advantages of layered and tunnel structures, and achieves highly reversible phase transition and excellent electrochemical performance, which delivers a high specific capacity of 178.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;C and capacity retention of 77.8 % after 100 cycles at 1&nbsp;C. The well-maintained P2 phase was revealed by the <em>in-situ</em> X-ray diffraction (XRD), demonstrating the highly reversible charge compensation and structural evolution. In addition, NMO-3M cathode shows a good storage performance in air over 270 days. This research designed a layered/tunnel interlocking structure induced by trace Mo doping to construct a stable and high capacity oxide cathode, providing a guideline for the preparation of excellent oxide cathodes for SIBs in the future.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/smll.202404280" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Sodium-Rich, Co-Ni-Free P2-Layered Manganese Oxide Cathodes for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Small</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsaem.4c01699" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Synergistic Effect of (K&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt;+Li&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt;) Cosubstitution on P2-Type Fe-Mn Oxide Cathodes for Sodium-ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, ACS Applied Energy Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d4ta04815f" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Construction of a stable interface at the Na&lt;inf&gt;0.67&lt;/inf&gt;Ni&lt;inf&gt;0.33&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;0.67&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; cathode using LiDFOB electrolyte additives for high-performance sodium-ion batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Materials Chemistry A</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span id="recommended-articles-article0-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724000795" title="Modulating the oxygen redox activity of an ultra-high href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X23027895" title="Construction of environmental-stable and high-rate layered oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Construction of environmental-stable and high-rate layered oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Energy Storage, Volume 74, Part A, 2023, Article 109391</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Zhenfei</span> <span>Cai</span>, …, <span>Ting-Feng</span> href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X23027895/pdfft?md5=f81dfa20173c6a8c0d1dcf7e4f530e0b&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S2352152X23027895-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article1-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 .596-.068.596-.673-.002-.6-.32-.667-.596-.667h-.542m3.8.036v2.92h.35c.933 0 1.223-.448     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
